children.name: confidence b2
children.definition: confidence the feeling that you have the ability to do things well, and to not make mistakes or be nervous in new situations: sự tự tin
examples: you need patience and confidence to be a good teacher.
have the confidence to do sth
‘we have the confidence to beat brazil,’ said sampson.
after the accident it took a long time before she had the confidence to get back in a car again.
full of confidencevery confident
i went into the test full of confidence, but it was more difficult than i had imagined.

children.name: self-confidence x
children.definition: self-confidence a strong belief that you can do things well and that other people will like you, which means you behave confidently in most situations: sự tự tin, lòng tự tin (về bản thân)
examples: he’s new in the job but he has plenty of self-confidence.
studies show that girls tend to lose some of their self-confidence in their teenage years.
students who get some kind of work experience develop greater self-confidence and better communication skills.

children.name: morale c2
children.definition: morale the level of confidence, satisfaction, and hope that people feel, especially a group of people who work together: chí khí, nhuệ khí, tinh thần
examples: low/ high morale
morale among the soldiers has been low.
keep up moralekeep it at a high level
they sang songs to keep up their morale until the rescuers arrived.

children.name: assurance c2
children.definition: assurance/ self-assurance a feeling of calm confidence in your own abilities, especially because you have a lot of experience: sự chắc chắn, sự đảm bảo, sự tự tin
examples: she envied the older woman’s assurance.
danby spoke to the committee with the self-assurance of an expert.

children.name: belief in yourself b2
children.definition: belief in yourself confidence in your own abilities, value, and judgment, which makes it likely that you will be successful at sth: lòng tin vào bản thân
examples: you must have belief in yourself if you want to make it as an actor.
to acquire that level of skill requires years of training and an unfailing belief in yourself.

children.name: self-esteem c1
children.definition: self-esteem the feeling that you are sb who deserves to be liked and respected: sự tự trọng, lòng tự trọng
examples: getting a job did a lot for her self-esteem.
sports should build a child’s self-esteem, not damage it.
she suffers fromlowself-esteem and it prevents her from pursuing her goals.

children.name: lose confidence
children.definition: to stop feeling confident, especially after making a mistake: mất tự tin
examples: ‘how was your driving test?’ ‘terrible - i made one small mistake, and then i just lost confidence.’
people tend to lose confidence if they’ve been out of work for a while.

children.name: lack confidence
children.definition: / be lacking in confidence to not be confident about your abilities or appearance: thiếu tự tin
examples: francine lacks confidence and needs a lot of encouragement and support.
i was fat, had no friends, and lacked confidence.
while girls lack confidence, boys often overestimate their abilities.

children.name: unsure of yourself c2
children.definition: unsure of yourself to not be confident, especially because you are young or you do not have much experience: thiếu tự tin
examples: at first, chris seemed nervous and unsure of herself.
he was only 21 and still very unsure of himself with girls.

children.name: insecure c1
children.definition: insecure not confident about making decisions, trying new experiences, or forming new relationships, especially because you are worried that you are not good enough:
examples: thiếu tự tin
ben’s parents’ divorce left him lonely and insecure.
insecure about
even though she’s a model, she’s very insecure about how she looks.

children.name: demoralized x
children.definition: demoralized if a person or a group of people are demoralized, they have lost all their confidence that they can succeed at sth and are unwilling to continue with it: bị mất tinh thần, suy sụp
examples: a demoralized workforce
many employees became demoralized and cynical when the company announced another round of job cuts.
utterly/ thoroughly demoralized
the team was a wreck - thoroughly demoralized after a humiliating season.

children.name: discouraged x
children.definition: discouraged not confident about sth you are trying to achieve, because you have had difficulty achieving it: chán nản, nản lòng
examples: i was very discouraged at the time, but i still hoped we could find a solution.
get/become discouraged
students with learning difficulties who do not have a dedicated teacher can become discouraged very easily.
discouraged by
discouraged by her failed marriages, she gradually withdrew from the world.
discouraged about
hartman was so discouraged about the way his performing career was going, that he gave up acting for writing.

children.name: give sb confidence
children.definition: giúp/ khiến/ làm ai đó trở nên tự tin
examples: teaching abroad was good for me. it gave me a lot of confidence.
‘the activities,’ said harris, ‘are designed to give children confidence in their reading abilities.’
give sb the confidence to do sth
the country needs the backing of the international community to give it the confidence to rebuild its war-battered economy.

children.name: boost sb’s confidence
children.definition: an event or action that boosts sb’s confidence quickly makes them feel more confident: tăng sự tự tin của ai đó
examples: winning this game will really boost the team’s confidence.
to boost my confidence i went for a haircut and bought some new clothes.

children.name: build (sb’s) confidence
children.definition: build/ build up (sb’s) confidence to gradually make sb feel more confident:
examples: bồi đắp sự tự tin cho ai đó
the games are designed to make maths fun and build up youngsters’ confidence.
build confidence by assigning tasks which draw on an employee’s areas of strength.

children.name: boost morale
children.definition: boost/ raise morale to raise the level of confidence and satisfaction among a group of people: động viên / cổ vũ tinh thần
examples: a pay raise would boost employee morale a great deal.
visits by celebrities and politicians were meant to boost morale among the troops.

children.name: boost sb’s ego x
children.definition: boost sb’s ego to make sb feel more confident about themselves, for example by saying good things about their appearance, character, or work: khiến ai đó tự hào / tăng sự tự tin cho ai đó
examples: it was nice to have my work praised for once -- it really boosted my ego.
the fact that jane was attracted to him boosted his ego quite a bit.

children.name: give sb a boost
children.definition: / a lift to make sb feel happier or more confident: khiến ai đó vui/ tự tin
examples: nothing could have given the team a bigger boost than the victory over canada.
when i was feeling down, talking to marion always gave me a lift.

children.name: shake (sb’s) confidence
children.definition: shake/ damage (sb’s) confidence if sth shakes or damages sb’s confidence, it makes them feel unsure of their abilities and less confident: làm lung lạc sự tự tin ai đó / khiến ai đó mất tự tin
examples: being fired really shook his confidence.
badly shaken
her confidence was badly shaken when she was involved in a car accident a few years ago.

children.name: demoralizing x
children.definition: demoralizing making people feel that they cannot be successful at sth they are trying to do, so that they become unwilling to continue with it: đáng nản, gây chán nản
examples: the demoralizing effects of unemployment
many of the teachers found the school board’s criticism unfair and demoralizing.
rivas says being on welfare was a demoralizing and humiliating experience.

children.name: take the wind out of sb’s sails x
children.definition: take the wind out of sb’s sails informal to make sb lose their confidence, especially by saying or doing sth unexpected: khiến ai đó nản chí / khiến ai đó mất tin tưởng
examples: last night’s defeat has taken some of the wind out of the team’s sails.

children.name: discourage b2
children.definition: discourage to make sb feel less confident about sth they are trying to achieve: làm thất vọng, làm nản lòng
examples: what discouraged me most was our lack of progress in the pay negotiations.
although the troubles in the financial markets have made him cautious, reid said they haven’t discouraged him.

children.name: discouraging x
children.definition: discouraging making sb feel less confident about sth they are trying to achieve. làm chán nản, gây thất vọng
examples: my father made a few discouraging remarks about my academic abilities that have stayed with me to this day.
despite discouraging viewing figures for their movie ‘for the boys’, paramount decided to try to make another similar film.
be discouraging to do sth
it’s very discouraging to find out that your own team members have been lying to you.discouraging that
it is deeply discouraging that the government can struggle with the nation’s budget for nearly a year and still fail to achieve anything.

children.name: confident b1
children.definition: confident sure that you have the ability to do sth well, and not worried about failing : tự tin
examples: it’s a difficult test, but she seems fairly confident.
he gave his speech in a strong, confident voice.
confident about
after living in france for a year, i felt much more confident about my french.
be/ feel confident about (doing) sth
i’m not very confident about going back to work.
confident of
baldwin is confident of victory in this year’s senate race.
confidently[adv] một cách tự tin
she answered each question confidently.
‘it’ll all work out in the end,’ said brown confidently.

children.name: self-confident b2
children.definition: self-confident  sb who is self-confident is very confident about their own abilities and is not shy or nervous in social situations: tự tin
examples: jess was only 12, but she was very self-confident.
i eventually became more self-confident as a public speaker.
supremely self-confidentextremely self-confident
she was supremely self-confident, with the gift of being able to talk on any subject whenever the camera was rolling.

children.name: sure of yourself x
children.definition: sure of yourself very sure that what you think is right, even when other people do not agree with you: tự tin, chắc chắn về bản thân
examples: he sounded so sure of himself that i didn’t bother to argue.
jenny was younger than her sister but seemed much more sure of herself.

children.name: extrovert c1
children.definition: extrovert sb who enjoys being with other people and getting a lot of attention from other people: người hướng ngoại
examples: jan says her twin babies are completely different: kelly is a real extrovert while jessie is quiet and thoughtful.
most actors are natural extroverts.
he’s a total extrovert who will talk to any stranger.
extrovert[adj]
the signore was extrovert and jolly and his wife was a wonderful cook.

children.name: self-assured c2
children.definition: self-assured very confident in your own abilities and able to deal calmly with other people, especially in public situations: tự tin
examples: having done this many times before, she was self-assured and spoke without notes.
on the surface dana was calm and self-assured, but i knew that this wasn’t completely the case.

children.name: assertive c2
children.definition: assertive sb who is assertive behaves confidently so that they get what they want: quyết đoán
examples: jack has a very assertive personality.
the course helps women learn how to be more assertive in the workplace.
assertivelymột cách quyết đoán
try to communicate assertively - not aggressively.
assertiveness[u noun] sự quyết đoán
the group has been given training in public speaking and assertiveness.

children.name: certainty b2
children.definition: certaintynounin no doubt
examples: [ u ] the state of being completely confident or having no doubt about something
_i'm unable to answer that questionwithany certainty.

children.name: security c2
children.definition: securitynounconfidence
examples: [ u ] the feeling of being confident in one's family and relationships
_most children need the security of a stable family life.
